trans-unit.source: CREATE ASSEMBLY on Azure SQL Database with CSharp
trans-unit.target: CREATE ASSEMBLY on Azure SQL Database with CSharp

trans-unit.source: Provides C# source code to issue CREATE ASSEMBLY to Azure SQL Database after first encoding a DLL file into a string that contains a long hexadecimal number.
trans-unit.target: Provides C# source code to issue CREATE ASSEMBLY to Azure SQL Database after first encoding a DLL file into a string that contains a long hexadecimal number.

trans-unit.source: This topic provides a C# code sample you can use to issue a <linkText>CREATE ASSEMBLY</linkText><title></title> statement to Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: This topic provides a C# code sample you can use to issue a <linkText>CREATE ASSEMBLY</linkText><title></title> statement to Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: For SQL Database, the FROM clause cannot accept the simple format of a path on the local computer that hosts the database.
trans-unit.target: For SQL Database, the FROM clause cannot accept the simple format of a path on the local computer that hosts the database.

trans-unit.source: An alternative is to first encode the binary bits of the assembly DLL into a long string containing a hexadecimal number.
trans-unit.target: An alternative is to first encode the binary bits of the assembly DLL into a long string containing a hexadecimal number.

trans-unit.source: Then give the string as the value on the FROM clause.
trans-unit.target: Then give the string as the value on the FROM clause.

trans-unit.source: To understand this topic, you must have already partially know the following:
trans-unit.target: To understand this topic, you must have already partially know the following:

trans-unit.source:
CLR Table-Valued Functions
Explains how the CREATE ASSEMBLY Transact-SQL statement works with other statements for the on-premises Microsoft SQL Server.
trans-unit.target:
CLR Table-Valued Functions
Explains how the CREATE ASSEMBLY Transact-SQL statement works with other statements for the on-premises Microsoft SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: DROP FUNCTION and DROP ASSEMBLY, if necessary to clean up a previous run.
trans-unit.target: DROP FUNCTION and DROP ASSEMBLY, if necessary to clean up a previous run.

trans-unit.source: Remember the location of the Microsoft .NET Framework assembly DLL file that you compiled from your own code.
trans-unit.target: Remember the location of the Microsoft .NET Framework assembly DLL file that you compiled from your own code.

trans-unit.source: You provide the location in the next step.
trans-unit.target: You provide the location in the next step.

trans-unit.source: Run the EXE for which the C# source code is given in this topic.
trans-unit.target: Run the EXE for which the C# source code is given in this topic.

trans-unit.source: Tell the EXE where your DLL file is.
trans-unit.target: Tell the EXE where your DLL file is.

trans-unit.source: Encodes your binary DLL into a long string containing a hexadecimal number.
trans-unit.target: Encodes your binary DLL into a long string containing a hexadecimal number.

trans-unit.source: Issues a CREATE ASSEMBLY statement with the hex string given in the FROM clause.
trans-unit.target: Issues a CREATE ASSEMBLY statement with the hex string given in the FROM clause.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>CREATE FUNCTION</linkText><title></title> to reference a method in your assembly.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>CREATE FUNCTION</linkText><title></title> to reference a method in your assembly.

trans-unit.source: T-SQL SELECT statement to call and test your function.
trans-unit.target: T-SQL SELECT statement to call and test your function.

trans-unit.source:
The preceding list makes no mention of...
execute sp_configure 'clr enabled', 1;
...because this is not needed for Azure SQL Database, even though it is needed for Microsoft SQL Server.
trans-unit.target:
The preceding list makes no mention of...
execute sp_configure 'clr enabled', 1;
...because this is not needed for Azure SQL Database, even though it is needed for Microsoft SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: If necessary for reruns, the T-SQL code to drop the function and assembly is the following:
trans-unit.target: If necessary for reruns, the T-SQL code to drop the function and assembly is the following:

trans-unit.source: The trivial C# code sample in this section can be compiled into an assembly DLL file.
trans-unit.target: The trivial C# code sample in this section can be compiled into an assembly DLL file.

trans-unit.source: This code sample contains the method CompareCaseSensitiveNet which is referenced later in a T-SQL CREATE FUNCTION statement.
trans-unit.target: This code sample contains the method CompareCaseSensitiveNet which is referenced later in a T-SQL CREATE FUNCTION statement.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the method is decorated with a .NET attribute named SqlFunction.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the method is decorated with a .NET attribute named SqlFunction.

trans-unit.source: A method that is decorated with this attribute can be called by your T-SQL as a function.
trans-unit.target: A method that is decorated with this attribute can be called by your T-SQL as a function.

trans-unit.source: The following sequence occurs when you run the EXE that is built from this C# sample:
trans-unit.target: The following sequence occurs when you run the EXE that is built from this C# sample:

trans-unit.source: The command line run of the EXE calls the Main method.
trans-unit.target: The command line run of the EXE calls the Main method.

trans-unit.source: Main calls the ObtainHexStringOfAssembly method.
trans-unit.target: Main calls the ObtainHexStringOfAssembly method.

trans-unit.source: The method outputs a SqlString that stores the assembly as a hexadecimal number.
trans-unit.target: The method outputs a SqlString that stores the assembly as a hexadecimal number.

trans-unit.source: Main calls the SubmitCreateAssemblyToAzureSqlDb method.
trans-unit.target: Main calls the SubmitCreateAssemblyToAzureSqlDb method.

trans-unit.source: The primary input is the SqlString.
trans-unit.target: The primary input is the SqlString.

trans-unit.source: The output is a CREATE ASSEMBLY call that is sent to Azure SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: The output is a CREATE ASSEMBLY call that is sent to Azure SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: When we compiled and tested the sample code for the EXE tool, we used the following:
trans-unit.target: When we compiled and tested the sample code for the EXE tool, we used the following:

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013, update 4
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013, update 4

trans-unit.source: Our project template type was the simple console application.
trans-unit.target: Our project template type was the simple console application.

trans-unit.source: .NET Framework 4.5
trans-unit.target: .NET Framework 4.5

trans-unit.source: Our Visual Studio project referenced the following assemblies for compile:
trans-unit.target: Our Visual Studio project referenced the following assemblies for compile:

trans-unit.source: Microsoft.CSharp
trans-unit.target: Microsoft.CSharp

trans-unit.source: System
trans-unit.target: System

trans-unit.source: System.Core
trans-unit.target: System.Core

trans-unit.source: System.Data
trans-unit.target: System.Data

trans-unit.source: System.Data.DataSetExtensions
trans-unit.target: System.Data.DataSetExtensions

trans-unit.source: System.Xml
trans-unit.target: System.Xml

trans-unit.source: System.Xml.Linq
trans-unit.target: System.Xml.Linq

trans-unit.source: The following code block displays an example of the command line that you would enter to run the EXE from the console.
trans-unit.target: The following code block displays an example of the command line that you would enter to run the EXE from the console.

trans-unit.source: The parameters in the command line are artificially wrapped here for better display.
trans-unit.target: The parameters in the command line are artificially wrapped here for better display.

trans-unit.source: For simplicity of explanation this example passes the password as a command line parameter.
trans-unit.target: For simplicity of explanation this example passes the password as a command line parameter.

trans-unit.source: A better design is to have the C# code obtain the password from a CONFIG file.
trans-unit.target: A better design is to have the C# code obtain the password from a CONFIG file.

trans-unit.source: After the assembly is stored in your Azure SQL Database server, you must run a Transact-SQL CREATE FUNCTION statement that references the method in the assembly.
trans-unit.target: After the assembly is stored in your Azure SQL Database server, you must run a Transact-SQL CREATE FUNCTION statement that references the method in the assembly.

trans-unit.source: The following block of Transact-SQL code includes a couple of nonessential SELECT statements to show proof that the database system has records for your assembly and your function.
trans-unit.target: The following block of Transact-SQL code includes a couple of nonessential SELECT statements to show proof that the database system has records for your assembly and your function.

trans-unit.source: Finally there is a SELECT that calls the function.
trans-unit.target: Finally there is a SELECT that calls the function.

trans-unit.source: The preceding Transact-SQL code block ends with a SELECT statement that calls the new function.
trans-unit.target: The preceding Transact-SQL code block ends with a SELECT statement that calls the new function.

trans-unit.source: You could place the SELECT statement into a stored procedure.
trans-unit.target: You could place the SELECT statement into a stored procedure.
